result.reason: DeviceScaleFactor is hardcoded to 100 in RdpProtocol.cs instead of auto-detecting the local device DPI, causing blurry or incorrectly scaled RDP sessions when the host system uses >100% DPI scaling.
result.approach: Replace hardcoded DeviceScaleFactor=100 with a computed value from ResolutionScalingFactor (same DPI source already used for DesktopScaleFactor Auto mode), ensuring both extended properties reflect actual device DPI.

attempts.raw_output:
Based on my analysis of the issue and the current code:

- Issue #1818 reports that mRemoteNG doesn't pass Windows DPI zoom scaling to the RDP session (text appears small at 150% zoom)
- The code in `RdpProtocol.cs` already has `RDPDesktopScaleFactor` with `Scale100/125/150/200/Auto` options and `ResolutionScalingFactor` (per-monitor DPI aware)
- **However**, `DeviceScaleFactor` is hardcoded to `100` (line 69) regardless of actual device DPI — this causes blurry rendering at high DPI because the RDP client needs both factors set correctly
- The Auto mode already auto-detects `DesktopScaleFactor` from the control DPI, but `DeviceScaleFactor` should also reflect actual device DPI
- Last comment was 2021 — stale but the root cause is identifiable

```json
{"decision":"implement","reason":"DeviceScaleFactor is hardcoded to 100 in RdpProtocol.cs instead of auto-detecting the local device DPI, causing blurry or incorrectly scaled RDP sessions when the host system uses >100% DPI scaling.","priority":"P3-enhancement","estimated_files":["mRemoteNG/Connection/Protocol/RDP/RdpProtocol.cs"],"approach":"Replace hardcoded DeviceScaleFactor=100 with a computed value from ResolutionScalingFactor (same DPI source already used for DesktopScaleFactor Auto mode), ensuring both extended properties reflect actual device DPI."}
```
